column1: kd/00-16 Still I Long For Your Kiss (Alternate Version) 1.mp3
column2: Still I Long For Your Kiss (Alternate Version)
column4: You told me once that this was your favorite song on Car Wheels. Here's an alternate version for you. It might not rock as hard, but I still think you'll like it.

When I hear this song, I think of that time when we were listening to it in your room in Cabot, and I pointed out how all the different instruments come in at different times to shape the song. You dug it. I liked showing you a new way to listen.
Remember when we saw Lu in Providence and she drunkenly sang this? And you and I were dancing real close? I was so fucking turned on.

This song is so simple and beautiful. I like how, on each verse, the sound is reminiscent of what she's singing about. For example, on the verse about the rain, listen for the rhythmic, "raindroppy" guitar.  Also check out my favorite moment, when the pedal steel comes in while she sings "I envy the sun...."  It sounds like heat!

I love this song, and I especially like listening to this cover vs. the Emmylou one below. Lu's is darker, in large part cause the fiddle solo is over the chords from the chorus, which are minor, whereas Emmylou's fiddle solo is over the verse chords, which are major.
See above.

We saw these guys in Nashville. But you don't know the backstory. Becky put this on a mixtape for me a few months ago. (It's from the Breaking Bad soundtrack.) The other day, I asked a friend from Nashville for music tips for our trip, and he said "You gotta check out my brother's band, The Silver Seas. They're playing on Friday. I'll get you on the list." Always leave room for serendipity, KD.

column1: kd/04-03 To Know You (Is To Love You).mp3
column2: To Know You (Is To Love You)
column4: Remember Toad?  Remember Anita, who used to sing there? I recorded this track for her at Quad Sound (the studio in PfoHo). It was a present for her grandmother.

column1: kd/05-06 You Hit The Nail On The Head.mp3
column2: You Hit The Nail On The Head
column4: What a fucking groove. Love the sound of the nail in the chorus. ("You hit the nail on the head [ding!]") And the wah guitar solo. Badass.
Becky recently turned me on to Kathleen Edwards. She wants Kathleen to be inspiration for our next album, the way that Lu was for the first one. I think you'd like this stuff.
This one builds so well. Love the piano. Nice string arrangment, too. Becky's inspiration for Birmingham (see below).
You know what's sexy? Songs that are really slow but rock super fucking hard. (See Essence.)

column1: kd/12-07 Don't Worry Baby [Mono Single Version].mp3
column4: I never listen to lyrics -- you gotta show me a new way to listen! -- but one time I looked up the lyrics for this one and was totally shocked. It's about a fucking drag race!

column1: kd/13-03 Way over Yonder in the Minor Key.mp3
column2: Way over Yonder in the Minor Key
column4: Insanely catchy melody. It's interesting how they sing in unison (not harmonies) a lot of the time.
Baby, we were born to run.
I recorded Cliff's album in Quad Sound. I think this is a beautiful song.
Here's a sweet song to remind you of Boston.  It's another Cliff tune I recorded, featuring the Everybodyfields from Johnson City, TN.

Ok, I'm just fucking with you. Although, I will say, my first band covered this, and when I pulled out that fiddle and played that solo, it brought down the motherfucking house. (Or, rather, the motherfucking high school gymnasium.)  So I have a soft spot in my heart for it.

column1: kd/18-04 Violinkonzert e-moll. Allegro molto appassionato.mp3
column4: One day, after yoga, I want you to lie down, put your headphones on, close your eyes, and listen to this. (Apologies about the very end.  Wish I had a better recording.)

column1: kd/22-15 I Heard It Through the Grapevine.mp3
column2: I Heard It Through the Grapevine
column4: Do the eyes-closed, headphone-listening thing here, but focus on the bass.  I have listened to this song hundreds of times, and I still discover new nuances in this bass part. Unreal.
Something to remind you of Georgia.
Another one. Mmm.
Live at the 9:30 Club.

column1: kd/24-12 Cold Beer and Remote Control (feat. the Indigo Girls).mp3
column2: Cold Beer and Remote Control (feat. the Indigo Girls)
column4: Also the 9:30 Club. Can you believe I played there?
A tune I'm working on with Becky. We're hoping to make it sound like an oldie, so I'm trying to write a Sam Cooke melody.
Inspired by Kathleen Edwards' Buffalo and a big fight that Becky got into with the rest of the band when we were on tour in Birmingham.

column1: kd/27-I wish I was the girl I was.mp3
column2: I wish I was the girl I was (demo)
column4: Slammin' chorus. This one is a hit. I mean, they're all gonna be hits, obviously... but this one especially.
This song reminds me of you, albeit for somewhat dubious reasons...
Another beautiful song with an amazing arrangement.

column1: kd/30-07 You Are What You Love.mp3
column4: This song just makes me sigh.
Fucking sexy.  I suspect you'll agree...

column1: kd/32-14 Angel From Montgomery (feat. Bonnie Raitt) (live).mp3
column4: Shivers.
A sweet song from the album Nashville.
Also from Nashville.
"Come on, try it now!"
Fingersnaps! That guitar! The string arrangement in the bridge! Fuck yeah.

column1: kd/37-03 The End Of Our Road.mp3
column4: Goddamn that dude could sing.  Best part is the very end when he's all like, 'Packin' up my clothes, walkin' out the DOOR!' Damn straight, Woman.
You know I don't listen to lyrics, but for some reason I really connect with the lyrics on this record. This song makes me think of you.
This one makes me think of you, too.
You know, KD, sometimes all you need is a simple -- but fucking rock solid -- groove.

column1: kd/41-03 In The Aeroplane Over The Sea.mp3
column2: In The Aeroplane Over The Sea
column4: This song reaches a place in my heart that no other song reaches.
My first recording, from way back in high school. Right now I'm picturing you listening to this and laughing. I like your laugh. :)
Not sure if you ever met Noam... he sang backup on Round Hill. (He was making this album at Quad Sound while we were making the Great Unknowns record.)

Another beautiful Noam tune. (The girl singing backup keeps trying to get into my pants. She used to live in Nashville and I was gonna hit her up for trip advice, but I didn't have the heart to tell her I was coming here with another woman.)

column1: kd/45-3-10 I've Got Dreams To Remember.mp3
column4: Can't make a mix for my Macon girl without some Otis! This song builds just brilliantly. The drum beat at the end is so slammin'.  And I love when he says 'ooh wee!' in the bridge.
Champagne and wine, what it's gonna be / Just as long, girl, as you see about me.
They long to hold you.
I love how, back in the day, you could write a song called 'The Happy Song' about nothing more than a girl making you happy... and people took it seriously.  Simpler times.
So heartbreakingly beautiful. (And note that the drums and bass don't come in until you're more than halfway into the song!)
Apparently the Po

column1: kd/53-25 Bring it on Home to Me.mp3
column2: Bring it on Home to Me

column1: kd/58-02 If You Want Me to Stay.mp3
column2: If You Want Me to Stay

column1: kd/59-06 Lollipop (feat. Jay-Z, Soopafly & Nate Dogg).mp3
column3: Snoop Dogg (feat. Jay-Z, Soopafly & Nate Dogg)

column1: kd/61-07 Signed, Sealed, Delivered I'm Yours.mp3
kd/64-02 We Can Work It Out.mp3
